slides.title: Configuring Location Groups and Pages
slides.ocrText: Configuring Location Groups and Pages

slides.title: Learning Objectives
slides.ocrText:
Lesson
objectives

• Describe the architecture of a location group
• Configure existing location groups
• Create and modify pages

slides.title: i Location
slides.originalNotes:
Location groups
The tab bar is the set of tabs that run across the top of the application. The info bar is the set of widgets that appear below the tabs but above the screen area. (In other words, they are the widgets in the horizontal gray strip just above the "Summary“ label.) Some location groups do not have info bars, in which case the gray strip is not visible- The menu actions are collapsed inside the Actions nmenu.
As the user navigates between locations in a location group, the menu links, menu actions, and info bar remain the same. The menu links are the set of clickable labels in the side bar (such as "Summary" or "Contacts"). A page is a location that contains a single screen in the main frame
slides.notes:
Location groups
The tab bar is the set of tabs that run across the top of the application. The info bar is the set of widgets that appear below the tabs but above the screen area. (In other words, they are the widgets in the horizontal gray strip just above the "Summary“ label.) Some location groups do not have info bars, in which case the gray strip is not visible- The menu actions are collapsed inside the Actions nmenu.
As the user navigates between locations in a location group, the menu links, menu actions, and info bar remain the same. The menu links are the set of clickable labels in the side bar (such as "Summary" or "Contacts"). A page is a location that contains a single screen in the main frame
slides.ocrText:
i Location groups G

A location group is a collection of locations used to provide structure and navigation
for a group of related pages through menus or other interface elements

Account Summary: Ray Newton

slides.title: i Pages
slides.originalNotes:
Pages
Pages are the most common location.

Ultimately, the "groups“ inside location groups are groups of pages- The contents of a location group consist of pages, child location groups, or both. A child location group is simply a sub-group of pages.

A menu link location ref (a "second level navigation") can point to either another page or a location group. In the example, the menu link points to a page and the screen contained by the page is rendered alone

in the screen area. In PolicyCenter a location ref mostly points to another page or screen-
slides.notes:

slides.ocrText:
i Pages Gi

A page is a location that contains a single screen in the main frame
- Used exclusively within location groups

- Menu link / location ref (in sidebar) pointing to a page

slides.title: i Architecture of a location
slides.originalNotes:
Architecture of a location group
In the base application, location groups consist of tabs in the tab bar (First-level navigations) and menu links (Second- level navigations).

A first-level navigation location group is a location group that a tab points to (either directly or through a forward). This type of location group is a "parent-level“ group- If it has an info bar and menu actions, those elements are displayed. A second- level navigation location group can contain pages and other location groups.

A second-level navigation location group is a location group that some other location group contains. This type of location group is a "child-level“ group- It typically does not have an info bar or menu actions. A second-level navigation location group typically contains only pages or child location groups.

A location group contains location refs. Each location ref points to either a page or another location group. When a location ref points to a page, clicking the label of the location ref (the menu link) renders the page, which renders the associated screen- When a location ref points to a location group, clicking the label of the location ref (the menu link) renders the location group as a set of menu links. The first location refs page is also rendered.
slides.notes:
Architecture of a location group
In the base application, location groups consist of tabs in the tab bar (First-level navigations) and menu links (Second- level navigations).

A first-level navigation location group is a location group that a tab points to (either directly or through a forward). This type of location group is a "parent-level“ group- If it has an info bar and menu actions, those elements are displayed. A second- level navigation location group can contain pages and other location groups.

A second-level navigation location group is a location group that some other location group contains. This type of location group is a "child-level“ group- It typically does not have an info bar or menu actions. A second-level navigation location group typically contains only pages or child location groups.

A location group contains location refs. Each location ref points to either a page or another location group. When a location ref points to a page, clicking the label of the location ref (the menu link) renders the page, which renders the associated screen- When a location ref points to a location group, clicking the label of the location ref (the menu link) renders the location group as a set of menu links. The first location refs page is also rendered.

slides.title: i Location
slides.originalNotes:
Location group and page configuration
The next section of this lesson discusses locationGroup-level configuration. The section after that discusses page- level configuration.
slides.notes:
Location group and page configuration
The next section of this lesson discusses locationGroup-level configuration. The section after that discusses page- level configuration.
slides.ocrText:
i Location group and page configuration

Two levels of configuration
+ LocationGroup-level
+ Entry point and navigation to location group
* MenuActions, TabBar, InfoBar
+ Permissions to visit

+ Location refs

« Page-level
+ Screen that a page renders
+ Page logic (visibility, editability)

+ Page labels

slides.title: i Information in location
slides.originalNotes:
Information in location group PCF
The menuActions property specifies the file to use for contents of the Actions menu. It is optional. The infoBar property specifies the file to use for contents of the info bar. It is optional. The tabBar property specifies the file to use for the contents of the tab bar. It is optional. Ctrl + Click on the value for the menuActions, infoBar or tabBar opens the file link.
slides.notes:
Information in location group PCF
The menuActions property specifies the file to use for contents of the Actions menu. It is optional. The infoBar property specifies the file to use for contents of the info bar. It is optional. The tabBar property specifies the file to use for the contents of the tab bar. It is optional. Ctrl + Click on the value for the menuActions, infoBar or tabBar opens the file link.

slides.title: i Entry points for location
slides.originalNotes:
Entry points for location group
In the example, the AccountFile location group has an entry point named AccountFile- It expects a single object of type Account, which is referred to within the PCF page as "account"-

Location groups can have multiple entry points- This is useful when a single location is referenced from different places with different known pieces of information. (For example, the Admin location group has 3 entry points.
Admin() - This means it is called without any arguments.
Admin(group
GroupBase) — If the Admin tab is viewed for a group then it needs the groupobject passed.
Admin.org OrganizationBase) - If the Administration tab is viewed for an organization it needs the organizationobject passed.
Most navigation widgets have an action attribute, which defines where to navigate when the widget is clicked. The syntax for an action attribute that navigates to a location is:
pcfLocationEnttyP ointmethod(objectList), where
LocationEnttyPoint is (one of) the location entry point(s) defined on the destination location's Entry Points tab.
method is the method used tonavigate to the location (either "push" or "go")- For location groups, this is almost always "go"
objectList is a comma-delimited list of zero to many objects- This list must match the number of objects and the type which are expected by the location entry point.

For example, in TabBar-pcf, the action for the Desktop tab is set to Desktop-go(), which is the entry point defined in the location group desktop-pcf-
slides.notes:
Entry points for location group
In the example, the AccountFile location group has an entry point named AccountFile- It expects a single object of type Account, which is referred to within the PCF page as "account"-

Location groups can have multiple entry points- This is useful when a single location is referenced from different places with different known pieces of information. (For example, the Admin location group has 3 entry points.
Admin() - This means it is called without any arguments.
Admin(group
GroupBase) — If the Admin tab is viewed for a group then it needs the groupobject passed.
Admin.org OrganizationBase) - If the Administration tab is viewed for an organization it needs the organizationobject passed.
Most navigation widgets have an action attribute, which defines where to navigate when the widget is clicked. The syntax for an action attribute that navigates to a location is:
pcfLocationEnttyP ointmethod(objectList), where
LocationEnttyPoint is (one of) the location entry point(s) defined on the destination location's Entry Points tab.
method is the method used tonavigate to the location (either "push" or "go")- For location groups, this is almost always "go"
objectList is a comma-delimited list of zero to many objects- This list must match the number of objects and the type which are expected by the location entry point.

For example, in TabBar-pcf, the action for the Desktop tab is set to Desktop-go(), which is the entry point defined in the location group desktop-pcf-
slides.ocrText:
i Entry points for location group

1. Define the entry point

- EntryPointName(ObjectName: ObjectType)

- Example: AccountFile(account:Account)
2. Define each object used in entry point as a variable on Variables tab
3. Navigate from a widget to a location group

- Syntax for an action attribute in the navigation widget
EntryPointOfLocation.go(objects ToPass)

slides.title: i Location
slides.originalNotes:
Location group property: canVisit
canVisit : The canVlsit attribute determines whether a user can visit the location group. If blank, the canVlsit attribute evaluates to true. When the attribute evaluates to false, the tab is not rendered in the user interface- For example, if the canVisit expression (perm-User.viewteam) in the location group Team .pcf returns false the user does not have permissions to view any team screen and the Team tab is not rendered for that user.

For example, aapplegate does not have access to the Team tab whereas su (Superuser) has access to the Team tab. Team tab is useful for admin or supervisors. canEdit: In addition to the canVisit property, single-screen locations and wizards also have a canEdit attribute- Location groups do not have the canEdit property. Editability for location groups is controlled at the level of each page-
slides.notes:
Location group property: canVisit
canVisit : The canVlsit attribute determines whether a user can visit the location group. If blank, the canVlsit attribute evaluates to true. When the attribute evaluates to false, the tab is not rendered in the user interface- For example, if the canVisit expression (perm-User.viewteam) in the location group Team .pcf returns false the user does not have permissions to view any team screen and the Team tab is not rendered for that user.

For example, aapplegate does not have access to the Team tab whereas su (Superuser) has access to the Team tab. Team tab is useful for admin or supervisors. canEdit: In addition to the canVisit property, single-screen locations and wizards also have a canEdit attribute- Location groups do not have the canEdit property. Editability for location groups is controlled at the level of each page-
slides.ocrText:
i Location group property: canVisit G&G

• lf canVisit evaluates to true, the tab or link to a location group is visible and
clickable

• Editability for location group is controlled at the level of each page

slides.title: i Steps for creating a location
slides.originalNotes:
Steps for creating a location group
When creating the location group, there is no requirement to add an extension to the filename, but it is a good practice to add the suffix Group-
slides.notes:
Steps for creating a location group
When creating the location group, there is no requirement to add an extension to the filename, but it is a good practice to add the suffix Group-
slides.ocrText:
i Steps for creating a location group G&G

1. Create new PCF of type Location Group
2. Set essential information:
- title
- Entry point with matching variable (Entry Points tab)
- Avariable for each object in entry point (Variables tab)
= MenuActions, InfoBar and TabBar
3. Add location references for all included pages and location groups
4. Call the new location group in the action property of a navigation widget

5. Deploy changes

slides.title: Page configuration
slides.ocrText: Page configuration

slides.title: i Page PCFs
slides.originalNotes:
Page PCFs
A page is actually very simple, as it typically contains just a screen with panel references to the views to embed within it However, the rendering of the page in Studio can look somewhat complex, as all the embedded elements are visible in the page.

Each location ref in the location group has a location attribute which specifies the location whichthe location ref points to. The location is typically a child location group or a page. If the destination location group or page requires one or more objects, then the location attribute must specify which objects to pass-
slides.notes:
Page PCFs
A page is actually very simple, as it typically contains just a screen with panel references to the views to embed within it However, the rendering of the page in Studio can look somewhat complex, as all the embedded elements are visible in the page.

Each location ref in the location group has a location attribute which specifies the location whichthe location ref points to. The location is typically a child location group or a page. If the destination location group or page requires one or more objects, then the location attribute must specify which objects to pass-
slides.ocrText:
i Page PCFs Gi

« Page PCF file shows references to all embedded content in Studio

* Page content: Screens, Toolbars, PanelRefs, DetailsViews, ListViews and others

« Menu links, Tab bars are also visible in the Page in Studio, but not part of physical page PCF
• Pages are referenced by location refs in location groups

* LocationPropertyOfLocationRef: EntryPointOfPage(objectsToPass)

slides.title: i Page properties
slides.originalNotes:
Page properties
Similar to a location group’s canVlsit attribute, a user can see links to (and therefore can navigate to) a page only if canVisit evaluates to true.

If canEdit mode for a page evaluates to false, then the page appears only in read only mode, even if startlnEditMode is set to true.
slides.notes:
Page properties
Similar to a location group’s canVlsit attribute, a user can see links to (and therefore can navigate to) a page only if canVisit evaluates to true.

If canEdit mode for a page evaluates to false, then the page appears only in read only mode, even if startlnEditMode is set to true.
slides.ocrText:
i Page properties G&G
• Title label of a page in the user interface comes from page's title property
• If canVisit evaluates to true, the link to a page is visible and clickable
« Apage is either in read-only or edit mode

+ If canEdit evaluates to true, the page has Edit/Update buttons
+ If startInEditMode is true, then page renders in Edit mode

i Steps for creating a page

1. Create new PCF of type Page
2. Set essential properties:
- title
- Entry point with matching variable (Entry Points tab)
- Avariable for each object in entry point (Variables tab)
3. Adda screen
4. Include panels for viewable and/or editable content

slides.title: i Steps for creating a page - continued
slides.ocrText:
i Steps for creating a page - continued

5. For editable pages:
- Set canEdit property
- Add Edit Buttons to the page's screen

6. In the location group that will contain the page, add a locationref widget for
navigation to the page

slides.title: Question
slides.ocrText:
Question G
When you navigate between locations in a location group:
•
oo a) What changes?
b) What remains the same?
SS oe ee oe oe oo

questionData.question: When you navigate between locations in a location group:
questionData.answer: Oo a) What changes? b) What remains the same? a) The contents of the screen area changes. b) The menu links, menu actions, and info bar remain the same.

slides.title: Answer
slides.ocrText:
Answer
When you navigate between locations in a location group:
•
oo a) What changes?
b) What remains the same?
a) The contents of the screen area changes.
b) The menu links, menu actions, and info bar remain the same.
SS Se ee eee eo

•
•
SS oe ee oe oe oo

questionData.question: What two things can a location ref point to?
questionData.answer: Acchild location group or a page.

•

Acchild location group or a page.
SS Se ee eee eo

slides.title: Question
slides.ocrText:
Question G
What happens if a location group's canVisit attribute evaluates to false?
•
•
SS oe ee oe oe oo

questionData.question: What happens if a location group's canVisit attribute evaluates to false?
questionData.answer: When a location group's canVisit attribute is false, the location group is not rendered in the user interface. For example, if the location group appears on a tab, the tab is not rendered at all.

slides.title: Answer
slides.ocrText:
Answer G
What happens if a location group's canVisit attribute evaluates to false?
•
•
When a location group's canVisit attribute is false, the location group is not rendered in
the user interface. For example, if the location group appears on a tab, the tab is not
rendered at all.
SS Se ee eee eo

slides.title: Question
slides.ocrText:
Question G
When viewing a location group PCF file in Studio, which Studio tab
• specifies how to navigate to a particular location group?
•
SS oe ee oe oe oo

questionData.question: When viewing a location group PCF file in Studio, which Studio tab
questionData.answer: Oo specifies how to navigate to a particular location group? The Entry Points tab. This identifies the "navigation name" of the location group as well as any objects needed when navigating to it.

slides.title: Answer
slides.ocrText:
Answer G
When viewing a location group PCF file in Studio, which Studio tab
oo specifies how to navigate to a particular location group?
•
The Entry Points tab. This identifies the "navigation name" of the location group as
well as any objects needed when navigating to it.
SS Se ee eee eo
